# Millennials

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

"Generation Y" redirects here. For other uses, see [Generation Y
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Generation_Y_\(disambiguation\) "Generation Y
\(disambiguation\)") and [Millennials
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Millennials_\(disambiguation\) "Millennials
\(disambiguation\)").

Part of a series on  
---  
[Generations](/wiki/Generation "Generation")  
  
  * [Lost Generation](/wiki/Lost_Generation "Lost Generation")
  * [G.I. Generation](/wiki/G.I._Generation "G.I. Generation")
  * [Silent Generation](/wiki/Silent_Generation "Silent Generation")

**Millennials** (also known as **Generation Y**) are the
[generational](/wiki/Generation "Generation") [demographic](/wiki/Demography
"Demography") [cohort](/wiki/Cohort_\(statistics\) "Cohort \(statistics\)")
following [Generation X](/wiki/Generation_X "Generation X"). There are no
precise dates for when this cohort starts or ends; demographers and
researchers typically use the early 1980s as starting birth years and the
mid-1990s to early 2000s as ending birth years. Millennials are sometimes
referred to as "echo boomers" due to a major surge in birth rates in the 1980s
and 1990s, and because millennials are often the children of the [baby
boomers](/wiki/Baby_boomers "Baby boomers"). The 20th-century trend toward
smaller families in developed countries continued, however, so the relative
impact of the "baby boom echo" was generally less pronounced than the
[post–World War II baby boom](/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom
"Post–World War II baby boom").

Although Millennial characteristics vary by region, depending on social and
economic conditions, the [generation](/wiki/Generation "Generation") is
generally marked by an increased use and familiarity with communications,
media, and digital technologies.[1] In most parts of the world, their
upbringing was marked by an increase in a liberal approach to politics and
economics; the effects of this environment are disputed. The [Great
Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession") has had a major impact on
this generation because it has caused historically high levels of unemployment
among young people, and has led to speculation about possible long-term
economic and social damage to this generation.

## Terminology

Authors [William Strauss](/wiki/William_Strauss "William Strauss") and [Neil
Howe](/wiki/Neil_Howe "Neil Howe") are widely credited with naming the
millennials.[2] They coined the term in 1987, around the time children born in
1982 were entering preschool, and the media were first identifying their
prospective link to the new [millennium](/wiki/Millennium "Millennium") as the
high school graduating class of 2000.[3] They wrote about the cohort in their
books _Generations: The History of America 's Future, 1584 to 2069_ (1991)[4]
and _Millennials Rising: The Next Great Generation_ (2000).[3]

In August 1993, an _[Advertising Age](/wiki/Advertising_Age "Advertising
Age")_ editorial coined the phrase _Generation Y_ to describe those who were
aged 11 or younger as well as the teenagers of the upcoming ten years who were
defined as different from [Generation X](/wiki/Generation_X "Generation
X").[5][6] According to journalist Bruce Horovitz, in 2012, _Ad Age_ "threw in
the towel by conceding that millennials is a better name than Gen Y",[2] and
by 2014, a past director of data strategy at _Ad Age_ said to NPR "the
Generation Y label was a placeholder until we found out more about them".[7]
Millennials are sometimes called _Echo Boomers_ ,[8] due to their being the
offspring of the baby boomers and due to the significant increase in birth
rates from the early 1980s to mid 1990s, mirroring that of their parents. In
the United States, [birth rates](/wiki/Birth_rates "Birth rates") peaked in
August 1990[9][10] and a 20th-century trend toward smaller families in
developed countries continued.[11][12] In his book _The Lucky Few: Between
the[Greatest Generation](/wiki/Greatest_Generation "Greatest Generation") and
the Baby Boom_, author Elwood Carlson called this cohort the "New
Boomers".[13]

[Psychologist](/wiki/Psychologist "Psychologist") [Jean
Twenge](/wiki/Jean_Twenge "Jean Twenge") described millennials as "Generation
Me" in her 2006 book _Generation Me: Why Today’s Young Americans Are More
Confident, Assertive, Entitled—and More Miserable Than Ever Before_ , which
was updated in 2014.[14][15] In 2013, _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)")_ magazine ran a [cover
story](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cover_story "wikt:cover story") titled
_Millennials: The Me Me Me Generation_.[16] _[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek
"Newsweek")_ used the term _Generation 9/11_ to refer to young people who were
between the ages of 10 and 20 years during the [terrorist acts of 11 September
2001](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"). The first reference
to "Generation 9/11" was made in the cover story of the 12 November 2001 issue
of _[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek "Newsweek")_.[17] Alternative names for this
group proposed include _Generation We_ ,[18] _Global Generation_ , _Generation
Next_[19] and the _Net Generation_.[20]

Chinese millennials are commonly called the 1980s and 1990s
[generations](/wiki/Generations "Generations"). At a 2015 conference in
Shanghai organized by [University of Southern
California](/wiki/University_of_Southern_California "University of Southern
California")'s US-China Institute, millennials in China were examined and
contrasted with American millennials[21] Findings included millennials'
marriage, childbearing, and child raising preferences, life and career
ambitions, and attitudes towards volunteerism and activism.[22]

## Date and age range definitions

A minority of demographers and researchers start the generation in the mid-to-
late 1970s, such as [Synchrony Financial](/wiki/Synchrony_Financial "Synchrony
Financial") which describes millennials as starting as early as 1976 and
ending at 1992,[23][24] [Mobilize.org](/wiki/Mobilize.org "Mobilize.org")
which uses 1976–1996,[25] [MetLife](/wiki/MetLife "MetLife") which uses birth
dates ranging 1977–1994,[26] and [Nielsen Media
Research](/wiki/Nielsen_ratings "Nielsen ratings") which uses
1977–1995.[27][28]

A majority of researchers and demographers start the generation in the early
1980s, with many ending the generation in the mid and late 1990s.
[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia")'s McCrindle Research[29] regards
1980–1994 as Generation Y birth years. A 2013
[PricewaterhouseCoopers](/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers
"PricewaterhouseCoopers")[30] report and Edelman Berland[31] use 1980–1995.
[Gallup Inc.](/wiki/Gallup_\(company\) "Gallup \(company\)"),[32][33][34]
[Eventbrite](/wiki/Eventbrite "Eventbrite")[35][36] and [Dale Carnegie
Training and MSW Research](/wiki/Dale_Carnegie "Dale Carnegie")[37] all use
1980–1996. [Ernst and Young](/wiki/Ernst_%26_Young "Ernst & Young") uses
1981–1996.[38]

Another majority end the generation in the late 1990s or early 2000s. A 2017
[viral video](/wiki/Viral_video "Viral video") from [BuzzFeed](/wiki/BuzzFeed
"BuzzFeed"), detailing the seven living generations of Americans, described
millennials as those born between 1981–1997.[39] On the American television
program _[Survivor](/wiki/Survivor_\(U.S._TV_series\) "Survivor \(U.S. TV
series\)")_ , for their 33rd season, subtitled _[Millennials vs. Gen
X](/wiki/Survivor:_Millennials_vs._Gen_X "Survivor: Millennials vs. Gen X")_ ,
the "Millennial tribe" consisted of individuals born between 1984 and
1997.[40] [Goldman Sachs](/wiki/Goldman_Sachs "Goldman Sachs"),[41]
[Resolution Foundation](/wiki/Resolution_Foundation "Resolution
Foundation"),[42][43] and a 2013 _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)")_ magazine [cover
story](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cover_story "wikt:cover story")[44] all
use 1980–2000. Millennialpolicycenter.org and SYZYGY, a digital service agency
partially owned by [WPP](/wiki/WPP_plc "WPP plc"), uses 1981–1998.[45][46][47]
The [United States Census Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United
States Census Bureau") uses 1982–2000.[48] [Pew Research
Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center "Pew Research Center") defines millennials
as being born from 1981 to about 1997, with no chronological end point firmly
established.[49][50] Career[FAQ](/wiki/FAQ "FAQ") uses years between
1982-2000.[51]

Demographers [William Straus and Neil
Howe](/wiki/Strauss%E2%80%93Howe_generational_theory "Strauss–Howe
generational theory") define millennials as born between 1982–2004.[2]
However, Howe described the dividing line between millennials and the
following [Generation Z](/wiki/Generation_Z "Generation Z") as "tentative",
saying "you can’t be sure where history will someday draw a cohort dividing
line until a generation fully comes of age". He noted that the millennials'
range beginning in 1982 would point to the next generation's window starting
between 2000 and 2006.[52]

In his 2008 book _The Lucky Few: Between the Greatest Generation and the Baby
Boom_ , author Elwood Carlson defined this cohort as born between 1983–2001
based on the upswing in births after 1983 and finishing with the "political
and social challenges" that occurred after the [September 11 terrorist
acts](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks").[13] In 2016, [U.S
Pirg](/wiki/Public_Interest_Research_Group "Public Interest Research Group")
described millennials as those born between 1983 and 2000.[53][54][55]

Due to birth-year overlap between definitions of Generation X and millennials,
and the tentative nature of generations, some individuals born in the late
1970s and early 1980s see themselves as being "between" the two
generations.[56][57][58][59] Names given to those born in the Generation X and
Millennial [cusp](/wiki/Cusper "Cusper") years include Xennials, The Lucky
Ones, Generation Catalano, and the [Oregon Trail
Generation](/wiki/Oregon_Trail_Generation "Oregon Trail
Generation").[59][60][61][62][63] Individuals born between the years 1995-2000
are said to belong to the generation "YZ" cusp. [64]

## Traits

Authors [William Strauss and Neil Howe](/wiki/Strauss_and_Howe "Strauss and
Howe") believe that each generation has common characteristics that give it a
specific character with four basic generational archetypes, repeating in a
cycle. According to their hypothesis, they predicted millennials will become
more like the "civic-minded" [G.I. Generation](/wiki/G.I._Generation "G.I.
Generation") with a strong sense of community both local and global.[3]
Strauss and Howe ascribe seven basic traits to the Millennial cohort: special,
sheltered, confident, team-oriented, conventional, pressured, and achieving.
Arthur E. Levine, author of _When Hope and Fear Collide: A Portrait of Today
's College Student_ describes these generational images as "stereotypes".[65]

Strauss and Howe's research has been influential, but it also has critics.[65]
Psychologist Jean Twenge says Strauss and Howe's assertions are overly-
deterministic, non-falsifiable, and unsupported by rigorous evidence. Twenge,
the author of the 2006 book _Generation Me_ , considers millennials, along
with younger members of Generation X, to be part of what she calls "Generation
Me".[66] Twenge attributes millennials with the traits of confidence and
tolerance, but also describes a sense of [entitlement](/wiki/Entitlement
"Entitlement") and [narcissism](/wiki/Narcissism "Narcissism"), based on
personality surveys showing increased narcissism among millennials compared to
preceding generations when they were teens and in their twenties. She
questions the predictions of Strauss and Howe that this generation will turn
out civic-minded.[67][68] A 2016 study by _SYZYGY_ a digital service agency,
found millennials in the U.S. continue to exhibit elevated scores on the
[Narcissistic Personality Inventory](/wiki/Narcissistic_Personality_Inventory
"Narcissistic Personality Inventory") as they age, finding millennials
exhibited 16% more narcissism than older adults, with males scoring higher on
average than females. The study examined two types of narcissism: grandiose
narcissism, described as “the narcissism of [extraverts](/wiki/Extraversion
"Extraversion"), characterized by attention-seeking behavior, power and
dominance”, and vulnerable narcissism, described as “the narcissism of
[introverts](/wiki/Introversion "Introversion"), characterized by an acute
sense of self-entitlement and defensiveness.”[45][46][69]

The [University of Michigan](/wiki/University_of_Michigan "University of
Michigan")'s "Monitoring the Future" study of high school seniors (conducted
continually since 1975) and the American Freshman survey, conducted by UCLA's
Higher Education Research Institute of new college students since 1966, showed
an increase in the proportion of students who consider wealth a very important
attribute, from 45% for Baby Boomers (surveyed between 1967 and 1985) to 70%
for Gen Xers, and 75% for millennials. The percentage who said it was
important to keep abreast of political affairs fell, from 50% for Baby Boomers
to 39% for Gen Xers, and 35% for millennials. The notion of "developing a
meaningful philosophy of life" decreased the most across generations, from 73%
for Boomers to 45% for millennials. The willingness to be involved in an
environmental cleanup program dropped from 33% for Baby Boomers to 21% for
millennials.[70] Millennials show a willingness to vote more than previous
generations. With voter rates being just below 50% for the last four
presidential cycles, they have already surpassed Gen Xers of the same age who
were at just 36%.[71]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Armstrong_Legalize_Marijuana_2001.jpg/220px-
Armstrong_Legalize_Marijuana_2001.jpg)](/wiki/File:Armstrong_Legalize_Marijuana_2001.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Armstrong_Legalize_Marijuana_2001.jpg "Enlarge")

Two early millennials advocate for the legalization of marijuana at a 2001
event

A 2013 Pew Research Poll found that 84% of millennials, born since 1980, who
were at that time between the ages of 18 and 32, favored [legalizing the use
of marijuana](/wiki/Legalization_of_marijuana "Legalization of
marijuana").[72] In 2015, the Pew Research Center also conducted research
regarding generational identity that said a majority did not like the
"Millennial" label.[73]

In March 2014, the Pew Research Center issued a report about how "millennials
in adulthood" are "detached from institutions and networked with
friends."[74][75] The report said millennials are somewhat more upbeat than
older adults about America's future, with 49% of millennials saying the
country’s best years are ahead though they're the first in the modern era to
have higher levels of student loan debt and unemployment.

Fred Bonner, a Samuel DeWitt Proctor Chair in Education at [Rutgers
University](/wiki/Rutgers_University "Rutgers University") and author of
_Diverse Millennial Students in College: Implications for Faculty and Student
Affairs_ , believes that much of the commentary on the Millennial Generation
may be partially accurate, but overly general and that many of the traits they
describe apply primarily to "white, affluent teenagers who accomplish great
things as they grow up in the suburbs, who confront anxiety when applying to
super-selective colleges, and who multitask with ease as their [helicopter
parents](/wiki/Helicopter_parents "Helicopter parents") hover reassuringly
above them." During class discussions, Bonner listened to black and Hispanic
students describe how some or all of the so-called core traits did not apply
to them. They often said that the "special" trait, in particular, is
unrecognizable. Other socio-economic groups often do not display the same
attributes commonly attributed to millennials. "It's not that many diverse
parents don't want to treat their kids as special," he says, "but they often
don't have the [social](/wiki/Social_capital "Social capital") and [cultural
capital](/wiki/Cultural_capital "Cultural capital"), the time and resources,
to do that."[65]

In his book _Fast Future_ , author David Burstein describes millennials'
approach to social change as "pragmatic idealism" with a deep desire to make
the world a better place, combined with an understanding that doing so
requires building new institutions while working inside and outside existing
institutions.[76]

Elza Venter, an educational psychologist and lecturer at Unisa, South Africa,
in the Department of Psychology of Education, believes members of Generation Y
are digital natives because they have grown up experiencing digital technology
and have known it all their lives. Prensky [77] coined the concept ‘digital
natives’ because this generation are ‘native speakers of the digital language
of computers, video games and the internet’. This generation spans 20 years
and its older members use a combination of face-to-face communication and
computer [mediated communication](/wiki/Mediated_communication "Mediated
communication"), while its younger members use mainly electronic and digital
technologies for interpersonal communication.[78]

## Workplace attitudes

There are vast, and conflicting, amounts of literature and empirical studies
discussing the existence of generational differences as it pertains to the
workplace.[79] The majority of research concludes millennials differ from both
their generational cohort predecessors, and can be characterized by a
preference for a flat corporate culture, an emphasis on [work-life
balance](/wiki/Work%E2%80%93life_balance "Work–life balance") and social
consciousness.

According to authors from [Florida International
University](/wiki/Florida_International_University "Florida International
University"), original research performed by Howe and Strauss as well as Yu &
Miller suggest Baby Boomers resonate primarily with loyalty, work ethic,
steady career path, and compensation when it comes to their professional
lives.[80] Generation X on the other hand, started shifting preferences
towards an improved work-life balance with a heightened focus on individual
advancement, stability, and job satisfaction.[80] Meanwhile, millennials place
an emphasis on producing meaningful work, finding a creative outlet, and have
a preference for immediate feedback.[80] In the article Challenges of the Work
of the Future it is also stressed that millennials working at the knowledge-
based jobs very often assume personal responsibility in order to make the most
of what they do. As they are not satisfied with remaining for a long of time
at the same job, their career paths become more dynamic and less
predictable.[81] Findings also suggest the introduction of social media has
augmented collaborative skills and created a preference for a team-oriented
environment.[80]

In the 2010 the _[Journal of Business and
Psychology](/wiki/Journal_of_Business_and_Psychology "Journal of Business and
Psychology"),_ contributors Myers and Sadaghiani find millennials "expect
close relationships and frequent feedback from supervisors" to be a main point
of differentiation.[82] Multiple studies observe millennials’ associating job
satisfaction with free flow of information, strong connectivity to
supervisors, and more immediate feedback.[82] Hershatter and Epstein,
researchers from [Emory University](/wiki/Emory_University "Emory
University"), argue a lot of these traits can be linked to millennials
entering the educational system on the cusp of academic reform, which created
a much more structured educational system.[83] Some argue in the wake of these
reforms, such as the [No Child Left Behind Act](/wiki/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act
"No Child Left Behind Act"), millennials have increasingly sought the aid of
mentors and advisers, leading to 66% of millennials seeking a flat work
environment.[83]

Hershatter and Epstein also stress a growing importance on work-life balance.
Studies show nearly one-third of students' top priority is to "balance
personal and professional life".[83] The Brain Drain Study shows nearly 9 out
of 10 millennials place an importance on work-life balance, with additional
surveys demonstrating the generation to favor familial over corporate
values.[83] Studies also show a preference for work-life balance, which
contrasts to the Baby Boomers' work-centric attitude.[82]

Data also suggests millennials are driving a shift towards the public service
sector. In 2010, Myers and Sadaghiani published research in the _Journal of
Business and Psychology_ stating heightened participation in the [Peace
Corps](/wiki/Peace_Corps "Peace Corps") and MeriCorps as a result of
millennials, with volunteering being at all-time highs.[82] Volunteer activity
between 2007 and 2008 show the Millennial age group experienced almost three-
times the increase of the overall population, which is consistent with a
survey of 130 college upperclassmen depicting an emphasis on altruism in their
upbringing.[82] This has led, according to a Harvard University Institute of
Politics, six out of ten millennials to consider a career in public
service.[82]

The 2014 Brookings publication shows a generational adherence to corporate
social responsibility, with the National Society of High School Scholars
(NSHSS) 2013 survey and Universum’s 2011 survey, depicting a preference to
work for companies engaged in the betterment of society.[84] Millennials'
shift in attitudes has led to data depicting 64% of millennials would take a
60% pay cut to pursue a career path aligned with their passions, and financial
institutions have fallen out of favor with banks comprising 40% of the
generation's least liked brands.[84]

In 2008, author Ron Alsop called the millennials "Trophy Kids,"[85] a term
that reflects a trend in competitive sports, as well as many other aspects of
life, where mere participation is frequently enough for a reward. It has been
reported that this is an issue in corporate environments.[85] Some employers
are concerned that millennials have too great expectations from the
workplace.[86] Some studies predict they will switch jobs frequently, holding
many more jobs than Gen Xers due to their great expectations.[87] Psychologist
Jean Twenge reports data suggests there are differences between older and
younger millennials regarding workplace expectations, with younger millennials
being "more practical" and "more attracted to industries with steady work and
are more likely to say they are willing to work overtime” which Twenge
attributes to younger millennials coming of age following the financial crisis
of 2007-2008.[88]

There is also a contention that the major differences are found solely between
millennials and Generation X. Researchers from the [University of
Missouri](/wiki/University_of_Missouri "University of Missouri") and The
[University of Tennessee](/wiki/University_of_Tennessee "University of
Tennessee") conducted a study based on measurement equivalence to determine if
such a difference does in fact exist.[89] The study looked at 1,860
participants who had completed the Multidimensional Work Ethic Profile (MWEP),
a survey aimed at measuring identification with work-ethic characteristics,
across a 12-year period spanning from 1996 to 2008.[89] The results of the
findings suggest the main difference in work ethic sentiments arose between
the two most recent generational cohorts, Generation X and millennials, with
relatively small variances between the two generations and their predecessor,
the Baby Boomers.[89]

That said, some research fails to find convincing differences. A meta study
conducted by researchers from The [George Washington
University](/wiki/George_Washington_University "George Washington University")
and The [U.S. Army](/wiki/U.S._Army "U.S. Army") Research Institute for the
Behavioral and Social Sciences questions the validity of workplace differences
across any generational cohort. According to the researchers, disagreement in
which events to include when assigning generational cohorts, as well as varied
opinions on which age ranges to include in each generational category are the
main drivers behind their skepticism.[90] The analysis of 20 research reports
focusing on the three work-related factors of job satisfaction, organizational
commitment and intent to turn over proved any variation was too small to
discount the impact of employee tenure and aging of individuals.[90] Newer
research shows that millennials change jobs for the same reasons as other
generations—namely, more money and a more innovative work environment. They
look for versatility and flexibility in the workplace, and strive for a strong
work–life balance in their jobs[91] and have similar career aspirations to
other generations, valuing financial security and a diverse workplace just as
much as their older colleagues.[92]

## Political views

Surveys of political attitudes among millennials in the United Kingdom have
suggested increasingly [social liberal](/wiki/Social_liberalism "Social
liberalism") views, as well as higher overall support for [classical
liberal](/wiki/Classical_liberalism "Classical liberalism") economic policies
than preceding generations. They are more likely to support [same-sex
marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage") and the legalization of
drugs.[93] _The Economist_ parallels this with millennials in the United
States, whose attitudes are more supportive of social liberal policies and
same-sex marriage relative to other demographics.[93] They are also more
likely to oppose [animal testing](/wiki/Animal_testing "Animal testing") for
medical purposes than older generations.[94] [Bernie
Sanders](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders "Bernie Sanders"), a self-proclaimed [democratic
socialist](/wiki/Democratic_socialist "Democratic socialist") and democratic
candidate in the [2016 United States presidential
election](/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election "2016 United States
presidential election"), was the most popular candidate among Millennial
voters in the [primary phase](/wiki/United_States_presidential_primary "United
States presidential primary"), having garnered more votes from people under 30
in 21 states than the major parties' candidates, [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") and [Hillary
Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton"), did combined.[95] In April
2016, _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_
viewed him as changing the way millennials viewed politics, saying, "He's not
moving a party to the left. He's moving a generation to the left."[96][97]
Bernie Sanders referred to millennials as "the least prejudiced generation in
the history of the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")".[98]
A 2014 poll for the [libertarian](/wiki/Libertarianism_in_the_United_States
"Libertarianism in the United States") _[Reason](/wiki/Reason_\(magazine\)
"Reason \(magazine\)")_ magazine suggested that American millennials were
[social liberals](/wiki/Social_liberal "Social liberal") and [fiscal
centrists](/wiki/Fiscal_centrism "Fiscal centrism"), more often than their
global peers. The magazine predicted that millennials would become more
[conservative](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the
United States") on fiscal issues once they started paying taxes.[99]

In the United Kingdom, the majority of millennials opposed [the British
withdrawal from the European Union](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit"). Blaming [Baby
boomers](/wiki/Baby_boomers "Baby boomers"), who largely supported the
referendum, one commenter said: "The younger generation has lost the right to
live and work in 27 other countries. We will never know the full extent of the
lost opportunities, friendships, marriages and experiences we will be
denied."[100][101][102][103] _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post
"The Washington Post")_ phrased this as "we let you steal our future",
reporting high voter turnout among those over 55 years of age and low voter
turnout among those under 34 years of age.[104][105][106][107][108]

### Political correctness

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Safe_Space_America_Truck.jpg/220px-
Safe_Space_America_Truck.jpg)](/wiki/File:Safe_Space_America_Truck.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Safe_Space_America_Truck.jpg "Enlarge")

A Safe Space America vehicle in 2016, which is used to promote the
availability and creation of [safe spaces](/wiki/Safe_space "Safe space")

In some countries, like the U.S. and UK, millennials are more likely to
support [political correctness](/wiki/Political_correctness "Political
correctness") than their elders.[109] In 2015, a [Pew
Research](/wiki/Pew_Research "Pew Research") study found 40% of millennials in
the United States supported government restriction of public speech offensive
to minority groups; agreeing with this were 27% of Gen Xers, 24% of Baby
Boomers and only 12% of the [Silent Generation](/wiki/Silent_Generation
"Silent Generation"). Pew Research noted similar age related trends in the
United Kingdom, but not in Germany and Spain, where millennials were less
supportive of restricting offensive speech than older groups, or France, Italy
and Poland, where there were no noticeable age differences.[110] In the U.S.
and UK, millennials have brought changes to higher education via drawing
attention to [microaggressions](/wiki/Microaggressions "Microaggressions") and
advocating implementation of [safe spaces](/wiki/Safe_space "Safe space") and
[trigger warnings](/wiki/Trigger_warnings "Trigger warnings") in the
university setting. Critics of such changes have raised concerns regarding
their impact on [free speech](/wiki/Free_speech "Free speech"), asserting
these changes can promote [censorship](/wiki/Censorship "Censorship"), while
proponents have described these changes as promoting
inclusiveness.[109][111][112]

## Demographics in the United States

Millennial population size varies, depending on the definition used. [William
Strauss and Neil Howe](/wiki/William_Strauss_and_Neil_Howe "William Strauss
and Neil Howe") projected in their 1991 book _Generations_ that the U.S.
Millennial population would be 76 million.[113]
Later,[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] using dates ranging from 1982
to 2004, Neil Howe revised the number to over 95 million people (in the
U.S.).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] In a 2012 [_Time_ magazine](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)") article, it was estimated that there were approximately 80
million U.S. millennials.[114] The [United States Census
Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau"),
using birth dates ranging from 1982 to 2000, stated the estimated number of
U.S. millennials in 2015 was 83.1 million people.[115]

In 2016, the [Pew Research Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center "Pew Research
Center") found that millennials surpassed Baby Boomers to become the largest
living generation in the United States. By analyzing 2015 [U.S
Census](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau") data
they found there were 75.4 million millennials, based on Pew's definition of
the generation which ranges from 1981 to 1997, compared to 74.9 million Baby
Boomers.[116][117]

## Economic prospects

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/1_-_Hamburg_1._Mai_2014_07.JPG/220px-1_-_Hamburg_1._Mai_2014_07.JPG)](/wiki/File:1_-_Hamburg_1._Mai_2014_07.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:1_-_Hamburg_1._Mai_2014_07.JPG "Enlarge")

German young adults protest youth unemployment at a 2014 event

Economic prospects for some millennials have declined largely due to the
[Great Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession") in the late
2000s.[118][119][120] Several governments have instituted major youth
employment schemes out of fear of social unrest due to the dramatically
increased rates of [youth unemployment](/wiki/Youth_unemployment "Youth
unemployment").[121] In Europe, youth unemployment levels were very high (56%
in Spain,[122] 44% in Italy,[123] 35% in the Baltic states, 19.1% in
Britain[124] and more than 20% in many more countries). In 2009, leading
commentators began to worry about the long-term social and economic effects of
the unemployment.[125] Unemployment levels in other areas of the world were
also high, with the youth [unemployment rate in the
U.S.](/wiki/Unemployment_rate_in_the_U.S. "Unemployment rate in the U.S.")
reaching a record 19.1% in July 2010 since the statistic started being
gathered in 1948.[126] In [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"), unemployment among
youths in July 2009 was 15.9%, the highest it had been in 11 years.[127]
[Underemployment](/wiki/Underemployment "Underemployment") is also a major
factor. In the U.S. the economic difficulties have led to dramatic increases
in youth poverty, unemployment, and the numbers of young people living with
their parents.[128] In April 2012, it was reported that half of all new
college graduates in the US were still either unemployed or
underemployed.[129] It has been argued that this unemployment rate and poor
economic situation has given millennials a rallying call with the 2011 [Occupy
Wall Street](/wiki/Occupy_Wall_Street "Occupy Wall Street") movement.[130]
However, according to Christine Kelly, Occupy is not a [youth
movement](/wiki/Youth_movement "Youth movement") and has participants that
vary from the very young to very old.[131]

A variety of names have emerged in various European countries hard hit
following the [financial crisis of
2007–2008](/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008 "Financial crisis of
2007–2008") to designate young people with limited employment and career
prospects.[132] These groups can be considered to be more or less synonymous
with millennials, or at least major sub-groups in those countries. _The
Generation of €700_ is a term popularized by the [Greek mass
media](/wiki/Media_in_Greece#Mass_media "Media in Greece") and refers to
educated [Greek](/wiki/Greek_people "Greek people") [twixters](/wiki/Twixter
"Twixter") of urban centers who generally fail to establish a
[career](/wiki/Career "Career"). In Greece, young adults are being "excluded
from the labor market" and some "leave their country of origin to look for
better options". They're being "marginalized and face uncertain working
conditions" in jobs that are unrelated to their educational background, and
receive the minimum allowable base [salary](/wiki/Salary "Salary") of €700 per
month. This generation evolved in circumstances leading to the [Greek debt
crisis](/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis "Greek government-debt crisis") and
some participated in the [2010–2011 Greek protests](/wiki/Anti-
austerity_movement_in_Greece "Anti-austerity movement in Greece").[133] In
Spain, they're referred to as the _mileurista_ (for €1,000 per month),[134] in
France "The Precarious Generation,[135]" and as in Spain, Italy also has the
"milleurista"; generation of 1,000 euros (per month).[132]

In 2015, millennials in New York City were reported as earning 20% less than
the generation before them, as a result of entering the workforce during the
[great recession](/wiki/Great_Recession_in_the_United_States "Great Recession
in the United States"). Despite higher college attendance rates than
Generation X, many were stuck in low-paid jobs, with the percentage of degree-
educated young adults working in low-wage industries rising from 23% to 33%
between 2000 and 2014.[136] In 2016, research from the [Resolution
Foundation](/wiki/Resolution_Foundation "Resolution Foundation") found
millennials in the UK earned £8,000 less in their 20s than Generation X,
describing millennials as "on course to become the first generation to earn
less than the one before".[137][138]

_Generation Flux_ is a [neologism](/wiki/Neologism "Neologism") and
[psychographic](/wiki/Psychographic "Psychographic") (not demographic)
designation coined by _[Fast Company](/wiki/Fast_Company_\(magazine\) "Fast
Company \(magazine\)")_ for [American
employees](/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States "Economy of the United States")
who need to make several changes in [career](/wiki/Career "Career") throughout
their working lives due to the chaotic nature of the job market following the
Great Recession. Societal change has been [accelerated](/wiki/Unbundling
"Unbundling") by the use of [social media](/wiki/Social_media "Social media"),
[smartphones](/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone"), [mobile
computing](/wiki/Mobile_computing "Mobile computing"), and other new
technologies.[139] Those in "Generation Flux" have birth-years in the ranges
of both [Generation X](/wiki/Generation_X "Generation X") and millennials.
"Generation Sell" was used by author [William
Deresiewicz](/wiki/William_Deresiewicz "William Deresiewicz") to describe
millennials' interest in small businesses.[140]

Millennials are expected to make up approximately half of the U.S. workforce
by 2020. Millennials are the most highly educated and culturally diverse group
of all generations, and have been regarded as hard to please when it comes to
employers.[141] To address these new challenges, many large firms are
currently studying the social and behavioral patterns of millennials and are
trying to devise programs that decrease intergenerational estrangement, and
increase relationships of reciprocal understanding between older employees and
millennials. The UK's [Institute of Leadership &
Management](/wiki/Institute_of_Leadership_%26_Management "Institute of
Leadership & Management") researched the gap in understanding between
Millennial recruits and their managers in collaboration with [Ashridge
Business School](/wiki/Ashridge_Business_School "Ashridge Business
School").[142] The findings included high expectations for advancement, salary
and for a coaching relationship with their manager, and suggested that
organizations will need to adapt to accommodate and make the best use of
millennials. In an example of a company trying to do just this, [Goldman
Sachs](/wiki/Goldman_Sachs "Goldman Sachs") conducted training programs that
used actors to portray millennials who assertively sought more
[feedback](/wiki/Feedback "Feedback"),
[responsibility](/wiki/Moral_responsibility "Moral responsibility"), and
involvement in decision making. After the performance, employees discussed and
debated the generational differences they saw played out.[85]

Millennials have benefited the least from the economic recovery following the
[Great Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"), as average incomes
for this generation have fallen at twice the general adult population's total
drop and are likely to be on a path toward lower incomes for at least another
decade. A [Bloomberg L.P.](/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P. "Bloomberg L.P.") article
wrote that "Three and a half years after the worst recession since the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression"), the earnings and
employment gap between those in the under-35 population and their parents and
grandparents threatens to unravel the American dream of each generation doing
better than the last. The nation's younger workers have benefited least from
an economic recovery that has been the most uneven in recent history."[143]

In 2014, millennials were entering an increasingly multi-generational
workplace.[144] Even though research has shown that millennials are joining
the workforce during a tough economic time they still have remained
optimistic, as shown when about nine out of ten millennials surveyed by the
Pew Research Center said that they currently have enough money or that they
will eventually reach their long-term financial goals.[145]

## Peter Pan generation

American sociologist Kathleen Shaputis labeled millennials as the _[Boomerang
Generation](/wiki/Boomerang_Generation "Boomerang Generation")_ or _[Peter
Pan](/wiki/Peter_Pan "Peter Pan") generation_, because of the members'
perceived tendency for delaying some [rites of passage](/wiki/Rites_of_passage
"Rites of passage") into adulthood for longer periods than most generations
before them. These labels were also a reference to a trend toward members
living with their parents for longer periods than previous generations.[146]
Kimberly Palmer regards the high cost of housing and higher education, and the
relative affluence of older generations, as among the factors driving the
trend.[147] Questions regarding a clear definition of what it means to be an
adult also impacts a debate about delayed transitions into adulthood and the
emergence of a new life stage, Emerging Adulthood. A 2012 study by professors
at [Brigham Young University](/wiki/Brigham_Young_University "Brigham Young
University") found that college students were more likely to define "adult"
based on certain personal abilities and characteristics rather than more
traditional "rite of passage" events.[148] Larry Nelson noted that "In prior
generations, you get married and you start a career and you do that
immediately. What young people today are seeing is that approach has led to
divorces, to people unhappy with their careers … The majority want to get
married […] they just want to do it right the first time, the same thing with
their careers."[148] Their expectations have had a dampening effect on
millennials' rate of marriage.

A 2013 joint study by sociologists at the [University of
Virginia](/wiki/University_of_Virginia "University of Virginia") and [Harvard
University](/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard University") found that the
decline and disappearance of stable full-time jobs with [health
insurance](/wiki/Health_insurance_in_the_United_States "Health insurance in
the United States") and pensions for people who lack a college degree has had
profound effects on [working-class Americans](/wiki/Working-class_Americans
"Working-class Americans"), who now are less likely to marry and have children
within marriage than those with college degrees.[149] Data from a 2014 study
of U.S. millennials revealed over 56% of this cohort considers themselves as
part of the working class, with only approximately 35% considering themselves
as part of the middle class; this class identity is the lowest polling of any
generation.[150]

Research by the [Urban Institute](/wiki/Urban_Institute "Urban Institute")
conducted in 2014, projected that if current trends continue, millennials will
have a lower marriage rate compared to previous generations, predicting that
by age 40, 30.7% of millennial women will remain single, approximately twice
the share of their single Gen X counterparts. The data showed similar trends
for males.[151][152] A 2016 study from [Pew Research](/wiki/Pew_Research "Pew
Research") showed millennials delay some activities considered rites of
passage of adulthood with data showing young adults aged 18–34 were more
likely to live with parents than with a relationship partner, an unprecedented
occurrence since data collection began in 1880. Data also showed a significant
increase in the percentage of young adults living with parents compared to the
previous demographic cohort, [Generation X](/wiki/Generation_X "Generation
X"), with 23% of young adults aged 18–34 living with parents in 2000, rising
to 32% in 2014. Additionally, in 2000, 43% of those aged 18–34 were married or
living with a partner, with this figure dropping to 31.6% in 2014. High
student debt is described as one reason for continuing to live with parents,
but may not be the dominant factor for this shift as the data shows the trend
is stronger for those without a college education. Richard Fry, a senior
economist for Pew Research said of millennials, “they're the group much more
likely to live with their parents.” furthering “they're concentrating more on
school, careers and work and less focused on forming new families, spouses or
partners and children”.[153][154]

According to a cross-generational study comparing millennials to Generation X
conducted at [Wharton School of Business](/wiki/Wharton_School_of_Business
"Wharton School of Business"), more than half of Millennial undergraduates
surveyed do not plan to have children. The researchers compared surveys of the
Wharton graduating class of 1992 and 2012. In 1992, 78% of women planned to
eventually have children dropping to 42% in 2012. The results were similar for
male students. The research revealed among both genders the proportion of
undergraduates who reported they eventually planned to have children had
dropped in half over the course of a generation.[155][156][157]

## Religion

In the U.S., millennials are the least likely to be religious.[158] There is a
trend towards [irreligion](/wiki/Irreligion "Irreligion") that has been
increasing since the 1940s.[159] 29 percent of Americans born between 1983 and
1994 are irreligious, as opposed to 21 percent born between 1963 and 1981, 15
percent born between 1948 and 1962 and only 7 percent born before 1948.[160] A
2005 study looked at 1,385 people aged 18 to 25 and found that more than half
of those in the study said that they pray regularly before a meal. One-third
said that they discussed [religion](/wiki/Religion_in_the_United_States
"Religion in the United States") with friends, attended religious services,
and read religious material weekly. Twenty-three percent of those studied did
not identify themselves as religious practitioners.[161] A Pew Research Center
study on millennials shows that of those between 18–29 years old, only 3% of
these emerging adults self-identified as "[atheists](/wiki/Atheism "Atheism")"
and only 4% self-identified as "[agnostics](/wiki/Agnosticism "Agnosticism")".
Overall, 25% of millennials are "Nones" and 75% are religiously
affiliated.[162]

Over half of millennials polled in the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom
"United Kingdom") in 2013 said they had "no religion nor attended a place of
worship", other than for a wedding or a funeral. 25% said they "believe in a
[God](/wiki/God "God")", while 19% believed in a "spiritual greater power" and
38% said they did not believe in God nor any other "greater spiritual power".
The poll also found 41% thought
[religion](/wiki/Religion_in_the_United_Kingdom "Religion in the United
Kingdom") was "the cause of evil" in the world more often than good.[163] The
[British Social Attitudes Survey](/wiki/British_Social_Attitudes_Survey
"British Social Attitudes Survey") found that 71% of British 18-24 year-olds
were not religious, with just 3% affiliated to the once-dominant [Church of
England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England").[164]

## Digital technology

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/People_using_cellphones_on_a_street_in_New_York.jpg/220px-
People_using_cellphones_on_a_street_in_New_York.jpg)](/wiki/File:People_using_cellphones_on_a_street_in_New_York.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:People_using_cellphones_on_a_street_in_New_York.jpg "Enlarge")

Three people who appear to be millennials using smartphones

In their 2007 book, authors Junco and Mastrodicasa expanded on the work of
[William Strauss](/wiki/William_Strauss "William Strauss") and [Neil
Howe](/wiki/Neil_Howe "Neil Howe") to include research-based information about
the personality profiles of millennials, especially as it relates to higher
education. They conducted a large-sample (7,705) research study of
[college](/wiki/College "College") [students](/wiki/Student "Student"). They
found that Next Generation college students, born between 1983–1992, were
frequently in touch with their parents and they used
[technology](/wiki/Technology "Technology") at higher rates than people from
[other generations](/wiki/List_of_Generations "List of Generations"). In their
survey, they found that 97% of these students owned a
[computer](/wiki/Computer "Computer"), 94% owned a [mobile
phone](/wiki/Mobile_phone "Mobile phone"), and 56% owned an [MP3
player](/wiki/MP3_player "MP3 player"). They also found that students spoke
with their parents an average of 1.5 times a day about a wide range of topics.
Other findings in the Junco and Mastrodicasa survey revealed 76% of students
used [instant messaging](/wiki/Instant_messaging "Instant messaging"), 92% of
those reported [multitasking](/wiki/Human_multitasking "Human multitasking")
while instant messaging, 40% of them used [television](/wiki/Television
"Television") to get most of their news, and 34% of students surveyed used the
[Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet") as their primary news source.[165][166]
Older millennials came of age prior to widespread usage and availability of
[smartphones](/wiki/Smartphones "Smartphones"), defined as those born 1988 and
earlier, in contrast to younger millennials, those born in 1989 and later, who
were exposed to this technology in their teen years.[88]

Gen Xers and millennials were the first to grow up with computers in their
homes. In a 1999 speech at the [New York Institute of
Technology](/wiki/New_York_Institute_of_Technology "New York Institute of
Technology"), [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") Chairman and CEO [Bill
Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") encouraged America's teachers to use
technology to serve the needs of the first generation of kids to grow up with
the Internet.[167] Some millennials enjoy having hundreds of channels from
[cable TV](/wiki/Cable_TV "Cable TV"). However, some other millennials do not
even have a [TV](/wiki/TV "TV"), so they watch media over the Internet using
smartphones and tablets.[168] One of the most popular forms of media use by
millennials is social networking. In 2010, research was published in the Elon
Journal of Undergraduate Research which claimed that students who used social
media and decided to quit showed the same withdrawal symptoms of a drug addict
who quit their stimulant.[169] [Marc Prensky](/wiki/Marc_Prensky "Marc
Prensky") coined the term "[digital native](/wiki/Digital_native "Digital
native")" to describe "K through college" students in 2001, explaining they
"represent the first generations to grow up with this new technology."[170]
Millennials are identified as "digital natives" by the Pew Research Center
which conducted a survey titled _Millennials in Adulthood._[75]

Millennials use social networking sites, such as [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook
"Facebook"), to create a different sense of belonging, make acquaintances, and
to remain connected with friends.[171] In the
[Frontline](/wiki/Frontline_\(U.S._TV_series\) "Frontline \(U.S. TV series\)")
episode "Generation Like" there is discussion about millennials, their
dependence on technology, and the ways the social media sphere is
[commoditized](/wiki/Commodity "Commodity").[172]

## Cultural identity

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Lesbian_Wedding_3.jpg/220px-
Lesbian_Wedding_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lesbian_Wedding_3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lesbian_Wedding_3.jpg "Enlarge")

Two women celebrate a [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex
marriage") in 2007

[Strauss & Howe](/wiki/Strauss_%26_Howe "Strauss & Howe")'s book titled
_Millennials Rising: The Next Great Generation_ describes the Millennial
generation as "civic-minded", rejecting the attitudes of the [Baby
Boomers](/wiki/Baby_Boomers "Baby Boomers") and [Generation
X](/wiki/Generation_X "Generation X").[173] Since the 2000 U.S. Census, which
allowed people to select more than one racial group, millennials in abundance
have asserted the ideal that all their heritages should be respected, counted,
and acknowledged.[174][175] Millennials are the children of Baby Boomers or
Generation X, while some older members may have parents from the [Silent
Generation](/wiki/Silent_Generation "Silent Generation"). A 2013 poll in the
[United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") found that Generation
Y was more "open-minded than their parents on controversial topics".[163][176]
Of those surveyed, nearly 75% supported [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-
sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage").

A 2013 Pew Research Poll found that 84% of millennials, born since 1980, who
were at that time between the ages of 18 and 32, favored [legalizing the use
of marijuana](/wiki/Legalization_of_marijuana "Legalization of
marijuana").[72] In 2015, the Pew Research Center also conducted research
regarding generational identity.[73] It was discovered that millennials are
less likely to strongly identify with the generational term when compared to
Generation X or to the Baby Boomers, with only 40% of those born between 1981
and 1997 identifying as part of the Millennial Generation. Among older
millennials, those born 1981–1988, Pew Research found 43% personally
identified as members of the older demographic cohort, Generation X, while
only 35% identified as millennials. Among younger millennials (born
1989–1997), generational identity was not much stronger, with only 45%
personally identifying as millennials. It was also found that millennials
chose most often to define itself with more negative terms such as self-
absorbed, wasteful or greedy. In this 2015 report, Pew defined millennials
with birth years ranging from 1981 onwards.[73]

Millennials came of age in a time where the entertainment industry began to be
affected by the Internet.[177][178][179] In addition to millennials being the
most ethnically and racially diverse compared to the generations older than
they are, they are also on pace to be the most formally educated. As of
2008[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Millennials&action=edit),
39.6% of millennials between the ages of 18 and 24 were enrolled in college,
which was an American record. Along with being educated, millennials also tend
to upbeat. As stated above in the economic prospects section, about 9 out of
10 millennials feel as though they have enough money or that they will reach
their long-term financial goals, even during the tough economic times, and
they are more optimistic about the future of the U.S. Additionally,
millennials are also more open to change than older generations. According to
the Pew Research Center that did a survey in 2008, millennials are the most
likely of any generation to self-identify as
[liberals](/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States "Modern liberalism in
the United States") and are also more supportive of
[progressive](/wiki/Progressivism_in_the_United_States "Progressivism in the
United States") domestic social agenda than older generations. Finally,
millennials are less overtly religious than the older generations. About one
in four millennials are unaffiliated with any religion, a considerably higher
ratio than that of older generations when they were the ages of
millennials.[145]
